facts.text: Assessee received dividends in previous years 1950-51 and 1951-52 from Associated Stone Industries Kotah Ltd. and Rajputana Mining Agencies Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Anant Rao B. Kamat, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, had received in the previous years  1950-51 and 1951-52  dividends from two companypanies, Associated Stone Industries  Kotah  Ltd. and Rajputana Mining Agencies Ltd.

facts.text: For assessment years 1951-52 and 1952-53, assessee claimed before Income Tax Officer that dividends should be grossed up under s.16(2) without rebate under Concession Order.

anchor.surface_text: For assessment years 1951-52, and 1952-53, the assessee claimed before the Income Tax Officer that the dividends received by him should he grossed up under s. 16 2,  of the Act, without taking into companysideration the rebate allowed to the said companypanies under the Part,

facts.text: Income Tax Officer disallowed grossing up at Indian rate but allowed at State rate defined by paragraph 3(v) of Concession Order.

anchor.surface_text: TheTax Officer disallowed the grossing up at the Indianbut allowed at the State rate, defined by paragraph 3  v of the Conclusion Order.The Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the order of, the Income Tax Officer,

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the order of Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the order of, the Income Tax Officer, but the assesse succeeded before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Assessee succeeded before Income Tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: but the assesse succeeded before the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal. On the application of the Commissioner of Income Tax, the tribunalreferred the following question to the High Court.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court on application of Commissioner of Income Tax under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: On the application of the Commissioner of Income Tax, the tribunalreferred the following question to the High Court. Whether the appropriate portion ofdividend received by the assessee fromof the said two companypanies

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the affirmative in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the appropriate portion ofdividend received by the assessee fromof the said two companypanies in the financialyear 1950- 51/1951-52 is to he increased at the rate applicable to the total income of the respective companypanies

facts.text: High Court asked for supplementary statement of the case.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, after asking for a supplementary statement of the case. answered, as we have already said in favour of the ass

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeals.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we agree with the High Court that answer to the question referred should be in the affirmative. The appeals accordingly, fail and are dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: Whether the appropriate portion of dividend received by the assessee from the said two companies in the financial year 1950-51/1951-52 is to be increased at the rate applicable to the total income of the respective companies for the financial year 1950-51/1951-52 and without regard to and benefit conferred by the T. C. 07-order 1950 that the companies would get in the matter of payment of tax by them on their profits accruing or arising to them in a Part B State and assessable for the assessment year 1950-51/1951-52?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the appropriate portion ofdividend received by the assessee fromof the said two companypanies in the financialyear 1950- 51/1951-52 is to he increased at the rate applicable to the total income of the respective companypanies for the financial year 1950-51/195152 and without regard to and benefit companyferred by the T. C. 07-order 1950 that the companypanies would get in the matter of payment of tax by them on their profit-, ,accruing or arising to then, in a r art B State

issues.text: What is the true construction of s. 16(2) of the Act? Specifically, whether the rate at which grossing up is to be done is the rate applicable to the total income of the company without taking into account any rebate allowed?

anchor.surface_text: The scheme underlying s. 16 2  and s. 18 5  seems to be this. Under s. 16  2  the dividends are grossed up and under s. 18 5  any sum by which a dividend is increased under s. 16 2  is treated as payment of income-tax on behalf of the shareholder. In this setting, let us examine what is the true companystruction of s. 16 2  of the Act. It is companymon ground that grossing up has to be effected in this case. The real point of companytroversy between the parties is regarding the rate at which it is to be done.

issues.text: Whether the benefit given by the Concession Order is a rebate within the meaning of s. 16(2)?

anchor.surface_text: This takes us next to the point that benefit given by the Concession Order is number a rebate at all. We cannot accept this companytention. The Concession Order itself uses the word rebate in paras 5, 6, and 6A.

issues.text: Whether the word 'rebate' in s. 16(2) only relates to rebate granted under the Indian Finance Act and not any rebate granted under the Concession Order?

anchor.surface_text: First, he urged that the word rebate in s. 16 2  only related to rebate granted under the Indian Finance Act,and number any rebate granted under the Conces- sion Order. He further referred us to r. 14 of the Indian Income TaxRules, which prescribes the certificate to be furnished bythe principal officer of a companypany under s. 20 of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Words 'exemption or other modification' wide enough to include rebate.

arguments.claim: Grossing up under s.16(2) uses rate applicable to total income without rebates, as a mechanical test regardless of hardship.

anchor.surface_text: The legislature has devised a mechanical test which has to be -Applied regardless of the hardship or the benefit which may accrue to an assessee. Therefore, we agree with the High Court that though the rate applicable is the rate which is actually applied, rebate if any allowed to a companypany, has number to be, as directed by s. 16 2 , taken into account.

arguments.claim: Benefit under Concession Order is a rebate as the Order itself uses the word 'rebate' in paras 5,6,6A.

anchor.surface_text: This takes us next to the point that benefit given by the Concession Order is number a rebate at all. We cannot accept this companytention. The Concession Order itself uses the word rebate in paras 5, 6, and 6A.

arguments.claim: Expression 'rate applicable to total income' in s.16(2) differs from same in Finance Act 1951 due to words 'without taking into account any rebate allowed'.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument. It is true that the same expression occurs in s. 16 2  and the sub-clause above referred to, but as pointed out by the High Court, the words without taking into account any rebate allowed or additional income-tax charged occur in s. 16 2  and number in the said sub-clause,

arguments.claim: Word 'rebate' in s.16(2) only relates to rebate granted under Indian Finance Act, not under Concession Order.

anchor.surface_text: First, he urged that the word rebate in s. 16 2  only related to rebate granted under the Indian Finance Act,and number any rebate granted under the Conces- sion Order.

arguments.court_reasoning: Word 'rebate' not qualified, wide enough to include any rebate by statutory orders.

arguments.claim: Rule 14 certificate under s.20 supports limiting rebate to Finance Act rebates.

arguments.court_reasoning: Form mentioning reduction cannot change meaning of 'rebate' in statute.

holdings.text: The answer to the question referred should be in the affirmative: the dividend is to be increased at the rate applicable to the total income of the companies without regard to the benefit conferred by the Concession Order.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we agree with the High Court that answer to the question referred should be in the affirmative. The appeals accordingly, fail and are dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreeing with High Court; s.16(2) mandates mechanical grossing up ignoring rebates under Concession Order.

holdings.text: Under s.16(2), dividends must be grossed up at the rate applicable to the total income of the company without taking into account any rebate allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The legislature has devised a mechanical test which has to be -Applied regardless of the hardship or the benefit which may accrue to an assessee. Therefore, we agree with the High Court that though the rate applicable is the rate which is actually applied, rebate if any allowed to a companypany, has number to be, as directed by s. 16 2 , taken into account.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mechanical test using rate of dividend payment year, ignoring rebates; words 'without taking into account any rebate allowed' distinguish from Finance Act expression.

holdings.text: The benefit given by the Concession Order is a rebate within the meaning of s.16(2).

anchor.surface_text: This takes us next to the point that benefit given by the Concession Order is number a rebate at all. We cannot accept this companytention. The Concession Order itself uses the word rebate in paras 5, 6, and 6A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concession Order uses 'rebate' in paras 5,6,6A; remission of tax otherwise leviable under Finance Act.

holdings.text: The words 'exemption or other modification' in s.60A are wide enough to include grant of rebate as under the Concession Order.

anchor.surface_text: That a rebate as such can be directed to be allowed under s. 60A of the Act seems clear to us. Me words exemption or other modification are wide enough to enable the Central Government to give rebate such as has been allowed under the Concession Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad language in s.60A empowers Central Government to grant rebates via orders like Concession Order.

holdings.text: The word 'rebate' in s.16(2) is not limited to rebates under the Indian Finance Act but includes rebates granted under other statutory orders like the Concession Order.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding his first companytention. we are unable to limit the meaning of the word rebate to rebate granted under the Indian Finance Act. The word rebate is number qualified and is wide enough to include any rebate which may be granted by other statutory orders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unqualified term 'rebate' encompasses all statutory rebates; not restricted to Finance Act.

holdings.text: The form of certificate under r.14 of Income Tax Rules mentioning reduction of rate cannot alter the statutory meaning of 'rebate' in s.16(2).

anchor.surface_text: The form of the certificate refer-, red to us which mentions reduction of rate cannot change the meaning of the word

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subordinate rule/form cannot override unambiguous statutory language.

The holding on increasing the dividend at the rate applicable to the companies' total income is grounded in Section 66A, which governs such computations.
Section 66A addresses the issue of whether dividends received are to be increased at the rate applicable to the companies' total income.
Para 6A explicitly provides for allowance of rebate, grounding the holding that the Concession Order benefit is a rebate under s.16(2).
The explicit rebate provision in Para 6A of the Concession Order supports the holding that 'rebate' in s.16(2) includes such statutory orders.
Section 66(1) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 provides the procedural basis for referring the question to the High Court, enabling the issuance of the holding.
Section 66(1) requires the formulation and referral of a specific question (issue) by the authority to the High Court.

Concept c4 mechanical test ignoring rebates grounds h5's broad interpretation of 'rebate' in s.16(2)
c5 that Concession Order provides rebates treated as under s.16(2) grounds the holding h3 that its benefit is a rebate within s.16(2)

c5 defines the Concession Order as providing rebates treated as under s.16(2), directly addressing whether its benefit is a rebate under s.16(2) in i3
